reviews.text: Despite The Outlook’s advantages, a hysterical, bookworm, couch potato, chain smoking wife beats it. Kubrick did not intend to create a film about evil’s Achilles heel, but I left with that message. Be a mess, but fight.
reviews.author: Sarah Vincent

reviews.text: With an out-of-this-world cast, "The Shining" remains a cult film, even after 44 years and it’s ideal for a cold winter evening.
reviews.author: Zofia Wijaszka

reviews.text: The supernatural joins forces with psychosis in Stanley Kubrick’s superb adaptation of a Stephen King bestseller.
reviews.author: Wendy Ide

reviews.text: Stanley Kubrick somehow manages to feel restrained and more ambitious than ever, delivering a harrowing and nightmarish case study in the impact of isolation and familial resentment.
reviews.author: Patrick Cavanaugh

reviews.text: The Shining might be one of the most accessible classics to new viewers of today to understand why it is, in fact, one of the greatest and most influential horror films of all time. The ending is still mind-blowing after all these years.
reviews.author: Manuel São Bento

reviews.text: Yet, The Shining, which was his third to last film, was akin to the genre films of his past such as Dr. Strangelove and 2001: A Space Odyssey where he explored the essence of humanity in a way unlike any other filmmaker.
reviews.author: Wesley Lovell

reviews.text: Kubrick sabotages his own thesis in the most knuckleheaded way conceivable: we can't be charged as accomplices in horror when there is no horror.
reviews.author: Jay Scott

reviews.text: Kubrick, however, doesn't really seem interested in the "shining" or in the hotel's supernatural forces generally... The result is a movie fatally flawed artistically.
reviews.author: John Brosnan

reviews.text: An unending roller coaster of terror that knows exactly how to get under the skin of anyone who watches it.
reviews.author: Cody Dericks

reviews.text: There are a few terrific thrills, and some eerie moments of dislocation that only Kubrick could achieve, but most of the movie is unfelt, unscary, and bizarrely heavy-handed. It's the first pompous haunted-house movie.
reviews.author: David Denby

reviews.text: The terrifying aspect of The Shining, and its most enduring quality, is how Kubrick has trapped us in his cinematic maze to search without hope of ever discovering an adequate answer outside of our own making.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: He's always been the caretaker. Yet he's not fully aware, unlike Phil in Groundhog Day, who improves himself over what could be millions of years. (An aside from Harold Ramis about that story's duration.)
reviews.author: Ray Pride

reviews.text: A true masterpiece.
reviews.author: Tony Black

reviews.text: Each viewing reestablishes The Shining as one of the greatest horror movies of all-time.
reviews.author: Brian Gill

reviews.text: I have never watched The Shining and not been blown away. It's an absolute clinic in atmosphere, tension, family drama, production design, cinematography, and so much more.
reviews.author: Kent Garrison

reviews.text: Primarily about building an atmosphere and a feeling of unease; something could pop out at any second, but it doesn't have to in order to startle viewers.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: (1980 Review) Aside from an occasional flash of brilliance it is tedious and, the fatal blow, not all that scary.
reviews.author: Bill Newcott

reviews.text: It just didn't speak to me. I thought it was way too long and a little too slow in pace.
reviews.author: Justin Brown

reviews.text: One of the best movies of all time...my favorite Kubrick film.
reviews.author: Brandon Collins

reviews.text: ...one of cinematic history's most lauded horror films.
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: "The Shining" is woke, both in that the movie subtly addresses complex social issues and because the in-universe clairvoyant act of shining allows characters to see past and future atrocities (some politically charged) that occurred in the Overlook Hotel.
reviews.author: Matthew Rozsa

reviews.text: [The Torrence's] night of anarchy, spearheaded by Nicholson's ferocity, has become one of cinema's most iconic and deranged events.
reviews.author: Luke Parker

reviews.text: It's an interesting movie, but not the ultimate work in its genre that some expected from one of the great directors.
reviews.author: Lee Lescaze

reviews.text: Nicholson gives the performance of his life here, subtly changing from a vaguely defeated family man to a maniacally leering American version of Eisenstein's Ivan the Terrible.
reviews.author: Richard Freedman

reviews.text: Kubrick takes the trash material of the book so seriously, giving us optical purity, frame by languorous frame. But the material can't support that kind of handling, and we're denied the few simple pleasures we expect from a scare movie.
reviews.author: Lawrence O'Toole

reviews.text: The altered tone suits Kubrick's gallows humor, which was always about confronting and critiquing his audience's baser impulses: reinventing The Shining as a slapstick comedy about murderous patriarchal insecurity is a daring move.
reviews.author: Adam Nayman

reviews.text: Kubrick gives Shelley Duvall's persona depth and importance.
reviews.author: Kathy Huffhines

reviews.text: Stanley Kubrick's efforts to mix fantasy and reality are resolved too often in overused scenes of the persecuted kid, threatened woman, loud effects, and a deluge of blood. The result is an excessively calculated and distant film. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jesús Fernández Santos

reviews.text: For the stout-hearted, The Shining is definitely worth seeing for Nicholson's performance as well as Kubrick's fancy camerawork.
reviews.author: Rick Chatenever

reviews.text: Kubrick is master of visual images, and many of the scenes display his brilliance. But much of the suspense ends in anti-climax, and Jack Nicholson and Shelley Duvall seem over-extended in trying to maintain the terror.
reviews.author: Bob Thomas

reviews.text: The Shining is a bonafide classic. By this point, almost every scene is so iconic, the experience of watching it - truly watching it - feels something like devouring a Greatest Hits collection.
reviews.author: Scott Wampler

reviews.text: Kubrick most definitely made an impressive horror film that not only contributed to the genre as a whole, it also left an indelible mark on many moviegoers.
reviews.author: C.H. Newell

reviews.text: A work of maximum-impact minimalism based on a slender, yet searing story by King.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: Stanley Kubrick is at top of his game.
reviews.author: Rachel Wagner

reviews.text: It is technically magnificent and eerily tense, like waiting for an ocean of blood to pour from an elevator shaft. The Krzysztof Penderecki score is deeply unnerving.
reviews.author: Sean Fennessey

reviews.text: What a picture that could have been: a modern ghost yarn with an excellent cast, directed by master technician Stanley Kubrick. Yet the result is a bore, sometimes gratuitously violent, and lacking logic as well as chills.
reviews.author: David Sterritt

reviews.text: When you sit down to The Shining, you sit down with normal expectations of being diverted, perhaps even being gripped, but not being undermined. But the film undermines you in powerful, inchoate ways.
reviews.author: Bruce McCabe

reviews.text: It is a film that feels tantalizingly incomplete, missing just a few crucial pieces that you feel certain you're bound to catch the next time around.
reviews.author: Sean Burns

reviews.text: Kubrick again plays off the awesomeness of the internal odyssey and the banality of ordinary human behaviour.
reviews.author: Richard Combs

reviews.text: The Shining buzzes madness and malevolence from every frame.
reviews.author: Jamie Graham

reviews.text: Anyone coming to this work for the first time should be forewarned that the will generate more giggles (and perhaps a yawn or two), but there is absolutely nothing here to fear.
reviews.author: Phil Hall

reviews.text: Shock effect and graphic imagery don't compensate for the sense of pointlessness and even distaste that is left at the end of the movie.
reviews.author: Ernest Leogrande

reviews.text: If The Shining isn't trivial, it certainly encourages one to think that it is. But, perhaps, even that's a change for the better. Generally, it's the other way around.
reviews.author: Derek Malcolm

reviews.text: One of the best scary movies ever made, one of the best scary movies even imaginable.
reviews.author: Tim Brayton

reviews.text: A masterpiece.
reviews.author: Ben Walters

reviews.text: The Shining is like a near-miss auto accident: You don't know how scared you really were until you start shaking a few hours later.
reviews.author: Ralph Novak

reviews.text: The first time I saw Stanley Kubrick's The Shining, I had to turn it off during three key moments... Perhaps this time, I prayed, [it] would seem almost comically silly. Yeah, not so much.
reviews.author: Simon Miraudo

reviews.text: ...above all a movie about spaces, and how few things are more frightening than not knowing which way to go.
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: Strange and deeply creepy.
reviews.author: Andy Lea

reviews.text: The technique is as overpowering as Nicholson's performance, which is both hammy and deeply disturbing.
reviews.author: Adrian Turner

reviews.text: Kubrick's compositions and Jack Nicholson going kill-crazy with an axe remain hard to beat on the big screen.
reviews.author: Alistair Harkness

reviews.text: It's all in the build-up: Kubrick sets the scene for the horror with meticulous care.
reviews.author: Killian Fox

reviews.text: Re-cut or not, The Shining remains one of the most viscerally disturbing films ever made.
reviews.author: Emma Dibdin

reviews.text: Deeply scary and strange.
reviews.author: Peter Bradshaw

reviews.text: It does for the 'horror' genre what 2001 did for the science fiction epic; it intensifies it, thereby making it more theatrical but at the same time giving it more depth.
reviews.author: Peter Ackroyd

reviews.text: Essential viewing. Prepare to be disturbed.
reviews.author: Ashley Clark

reviews.text: Its artful ambiguities are immersive. Check in.
reviews.author: Kevin Harley

reviews.text: As in 2001, Kubrick likes ghost stories more than I do. And he gives me enough else, in the way of acting and bizarrely beautiful surroundings, to keep me happy.
reviews.author: Robert Hatch

reviews.text: Stanley Kubrick's film is a work of art that will continue to be broken down and explored for decades to come...
reviews.author: Felix Vasquez Jr.

reviews.text: Kubrick doesn't dumb it down or anything, but he's not actively trying to appeal only to film connoisseurs either. If any of his movies could be called mainstream, it's this one.
reviews.author: Jeremy Knox

reviews.text: Kubrick has made a movie that will have to be reckoned with on the highest level.
reviews.author: Richard Schickel

reviews.text: "The Shining" is an intense and not always ingratiating experience, a natural bookend to "2001"...
reviews.author: Rob Gonsalves

reviews.text: As a ghost story and adaptation of the Stephen King novel, it's largely a failure. On the other hand, as an example of directorial bravura and as a study of madness and the unreliable narrator, it's a brilliant success.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: The result may not quite match Kubrick's greatest films, but it is enthralling and hypnotic - a brilliant, ambitious attempt to shoot a horror film without the Gothic trappings.
reviews.author: Steve Biodrowski

reviews.text: It's arguably the talented director's least appealing film, as it feels empty and soulless.
reviews.author: Dennis Schwartz

reviews.text: It's the experience more so than the actual content of The Shining that radiates cold, anti-humanly indifferent terror.
reviews.author: Eric Henderson

reviews.text: Ostensibly a haunted house story, it manages to traverse a complex world of incipient madness, spectral murder and supernatural visions... and also makes you jump.
reviews.author: Ian Nathan

reviews.text: One of the late 20th century's finest tales of the supernatural and a justly famous classic.
reviews.author: Film4 Staff

reviews.text: Kubrick is after a cool, sunlit vision of hell, born in the bosom of the nuclear family, but his imagery -- with its compulsive symmetry and brightness -- is too banal to sustain interest, while the incredibly slack narrative line forestalls suspense.
reviews.author: Dave Kehr

reviews.text: The movie is not about ghosts but about madness and the energies it sets loose in an isolated situation primed to magnify them.
reviews.author: Roger Ebert

reviews.text: With remarkable visual panache and a keen sense of irony, Stanley Kubrick rehabilitates Stephen King's trashy, terrifying novel.
With everything to work with, director Stanley Kubrick has teamed with jumpy Jack Nicholson to destroy all that was so terrifying about Stephen King's bestseller.
reviews.author: Variety Staff

reviews.text: Kubrick's mostly riveting attempt to rewrite the conventions of the horror genre
reviews.author: Dan Jardine

reviews.text: Kubrick's use of space and the eerie steadycam have never been put to better use.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: Kubrick's spellbinding 1980 horror epic is one of the true masterpieces to come out of the genre. And Nicholson's descent into unbridled insanity is simply unforgettable.
reviews.author: Chuck O'Leary

reviews.text: I fear all work and no play has made Stanley a dull boy.
reviews.author: Eleanor Ringel Cater

reviews.text: If Stanley Kubrick's The Shining is not the best haunted house movie ever made, it is certainly among the most intricately constructed.
reviews.author: Leo Goldsmith

reviews.text: "Here's Johnny!" ... Kubrick's grandiose Jack-in-a-box shocker is a fright, but it's hardly up to his earlier brilliance.
reviews.author: Thomas Delapa

reviews.text: Regardless of how you read the film, there's little denying that it's a masterful work.
reviews.author: Ken Hanke

reviews.text: The Shining goes halfway toward bringing back Franz Kafka's understanding of real horror as the evil that lies within.
reviews.author: Frederic and Mary Ann Brussat

reviews.text: An immortal classic.
reviews.author: Andreas Samuelson

reviews.text: One of Kubrick's most severely overcooked, overdetermined projects; Duvall fascinates, but the rest bores and wearies.
reviews.author: Nick Davis

reviews.text: Among a handful of the scariest movies ever made.
reviews.author: Jon Niccum

reviews.text: The beauty of Kubrick's film is the ambiguity of it all . . . will leave the gears turning long after the credits stop.
reviews.author: Brian Mckay

reviews.text: The trappings are brilliant, but Kubrick ultimately loses the essence of the source material - and he's too good to expect anything less.
reviews.author: Rob Vaux

reviews.text: I can't recall a more elaborately ineffective scare movie.
reviews.author: Gary Arnold

reviews.text: Among that rare class of adaptations: it is as good as or better than the source material.
reviews.author: Michael W. Phillips, Jr.

reviews.text: A mysterious, haunting, visual experience.
reviews.author: Jeremiah Kipp

reviews.text: Boy will it chill your blood.
reviews.author: Almar Haflidason

reviews.text: By the second hour all hell breaks loose, and in the last few minutes it's sheer terror.
reviews.author: John J. Puccio

reviews.text: One of the scariest films I've ever seen. And I'm not easily scared.
reviews.author: Ted Prigge

reviews.text: Kubrick isn't out for screams, but he manages to make his movie thoroughly unnerving by keeping the horror so close to home.
reviews.author: Janet Maslin

reviews.text: A deliberately paced, but endlessly creepy, horrifying motion picture.
reviews.author: Dustin Putman

reviews.text: A camp classic that brings up some good psychological scares, yet is also abundant with laughs.
reviews.author: Matt Easterbrook

reviews.text: Weird as it sounds, this creepy thriller works.
reviews.author: Marjorie Baumgarten

reviews.text: Not Kubrick's greatest work (let's be honest: entire sections of this film make no sense at all), but hey, it's creepy as hell.
reviews.author: Christopher Null

reviews.text: The Shining (1980) is creative director Stanley Kubrick's intense, epic, gothic horror film masterpiece - a beautiful, stylish work that distanced itself
reviews.author: Tim Dirks

reviews.text: one of those rare thrillers that actually benefits from repeated viewings, although the movie is so unnerving many viewers have never made it all the way through even once.
reviews.author: James Sanford

reviews.text: Chilling, majestic piece of cinematic fright.
reviews.author: JoBlo

reviews.text: Kubrick's showcase of abilities, both with the camera and his characters, are incomparably haunting.
reviews.author: David Keyes

reviews.text: Strays from the source material, but still a creepy classic.
reviews.author: Scott Weinberg

reviews.text: The idea of the haunted house is turned completely inside out
reviews.author: Shane Burridge

synopsis: Jack Torrance (Jack Nicholson) becomes winter caretaker at the isolated Overlook Hotel in Colorado, hoping to cure his writer's block. He settles in along with his wife, Wendy (Shelley Duvall), and his son, Danny (Danny Lloyd), who is plagued by psychic premonitions. As Jack's writing goes nowhere and Danny's visions become more disturbing, Jack discovers the hotel's dark secrets and begins to unravel into a homicidal maniac hell-bent on terrorizing his family.
